questions.text: A patient comes with palpitation to ER. His Pulse-180/min and BP-70mm of Hg systolic. ECG shows narrow QRS complex tachycardia with regular heart rate. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DC cardioversion

 

For a patient presenting with hemodynamically unstable symptoms such as a significantly low blood pressure and a high heart rate, as indicated by a pulse of 180/min and systolic BP of 70 mmHg, immediate DC cardioversion is indicated. This procedure is critical for restoring normal heart rhythm and preventing further cardiovascular compromise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valsalva Maneuver: it is typically used in stable patients to attempt cardioversion of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) back to a normal rhythm. It is not suitable for patients showing signs of hemodynamic instability.

 

Option C. Adenosine: it is effective in terminating certain types of SVT by temporarily blocking the AV node but is used in stable patients. Given the patient's low BP, this is not the first-line approach.

 

Option D. Verapamil: it is a calcium channel blocker used for rate control in cases of SVT, more appropriate for stable patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DC cardioversion is the emergency treatment of choice for a patient with hemodynamically unstable narrow QRS complex tachycardia, as it quickly restores normal rhythm and stabilizes the patient.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Cardiology/SVT/chap 246

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with widespread edema, skin ulcers, and high blood pressure. Urine analysis reveals subnephrotic proteinuria (<2g/day) and microscopic hematuria. Serum complement levels are reduced, and she tests positive for anti-hepatitis C antibodies. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Essential Mixed Cryoglobulinemia

 

Explanation: 

 

Essential mixed cryoglobulinemia is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings. The patient presents with the classic triad of purpura (skin ulcers), arthralgia, and weakness. This condition is strongly associated with hepatitis C infection, which the patient tests positive for. The presence of hypocomplementemia (reduced serum complement levels) along with mild proteinuria and hematuria further supports this diagnosis. Mixed cryoglobulinemia typically involves a vasculitic process that can present with skin lesions and kidney manifestations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post-streptococcal Glomerulonephritis: While post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis can present with hypocomplementemia and hematuria, it typically occurs after streptococcal infections, not hepatitis C. It generally affects children and young adults, and the patient's age (60) makes this less likely. Additionally, it doesn't typically cause the widespread edema and skin ulcers described.

 

Option C. Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis (MPGN): MPGN can be associated with hepatitis C and low complement levels. However, MPGN typically presents with more significant proteinuria (often nephrotic range) than described in this case. While MPGN can be secondary to cryoglobulinemia, the clinical presentation more directly points to cryoglobulinemia as the primary diagnosis.

 

Option D. Focal Segmental Glomerular Sclerosis (FSGS): FSGS is not typically associated with hepatitis C infection or hypocomplementemia. It usually presents with significant proteinuria (often nephrotic range) without the systemic manifestations seen in this patient (skin ulcers, vasculitis).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hepatitis C virus infection is strongly associated with mixed cryoglobulinemia, which can manifest with skin lesions, arthralgia, weakness, hypocomplementemia, and kidney involvement with subnephrotic proteinuria and microscopic hematuria.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of HTN, DM2, and DLP is brought to the ER because of reports of palpitations and dizziness. ECG is ordered and shown in the image. His temperature is 36.8Â°C, PR is 106/min, RR is 18/min, BP is 84/46 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. What is the next step? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. DC shock

 

The patient presents with symptoms of palpitations and dizziness and is found to have an irregularly irregular rhythm on ECG, consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF). The absence of distinct P waves and the presence of fibrillatory waves further support this diagnosis.

 

The patient's vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 84/46 mm Hg, indicating hemodynamic instability. In cases of tachyarrhythmias such as AF, the management approach depends on the patient's hemodynamic status. For patients who are hemodynamically unstable, immediate intervention is required.

 

Synchronized DC cardioversion is the treatment of choice in hemodynamically unstable patients with AF. This procedure involves delivering a synchronized shock to restore normal rhythm. The shock is timed (synchronized) to occur at the peak of the R wave to avoid inducing ventricular fibrillation.

 

Specific contraindications for using synchronized direct current (DC) cardioversion (synchronized DC shocking) are sinus tachycardia, multifocal atrial tachycardia digoxin toxicity. But in cases where a patient is unstable and experiencing shock, immediate cardioversion is necessary despite these contraindications, underscoring the urgency in treating life-threatening arrhythmias in acute settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant used to prevent thromboembolic events in patients with AF. However, it is not the immediate intervention of choice for hemodynamically unstable patients. The priority in such cases is to stabilize the patient's condition, which requires electrical cardioversion.

 

Option B. Beta blocker: Beta blockers are used to control the heart rate in AF. They are not appropriate for initial management in an unstable patient, as they do not address the immediate need to restore a stable rhythm.

 

Option C. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic that can be used in the management of AF. However, it is typically used in stable patients or after electrical cardioversion has been attempted. In an unstable patient, immediate electrical cardioversion is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hemodynamically unstable patients with atrial fibrillation, immediate synchronized DC cardioversion is the next step to restore a stable rhythm and improve hemodynamic status.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with excessive fatigability towards the end of the day that improved with rest. He also gives a history of ptosis, difficulty in speech, and swallowing. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myasthenia gravis

 

Myasthenia gravis is characterized by fatigability that worsens with activity and improves with rest. The symptoms of ptosis, difficulty in speech, and swallowing are also indicative of myasthenia gravis, a disorder caused by autoimmune destruction of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle weakness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lambert-Eaton syndrome: Typically improves with activity and is associated with small cell lung cancer.

 

Option C. Duchenne muscular dystrophy: Presents with progressive muscle weakness from childhood, not with fluctuating symptoms.

 

Option D. Systemic lupus erythematosus: Can cause various neurological symptoms but not typically fluctuating muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis presents with fluctuating muscle weakness that improves with rest, and symptoms like ptosis, and difficulty in speech and swallowing.

questions.text: Which type of anemia responds to treatment with erythropoietin (EPO) therapy? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anemia due to renal failure

 

Anemia due to renal failure (chronic kidney disease) is the type of anemia that responds to erythropoietin (EPO) treatment. 

 

One of the key pathophysiological mechanisms in anemia of chronic kidney disease is erythropoietin deficiency, as the kidneys are the primary source of EPO production. When kidney function declines, EPO production decreases, leading to anemia. 

 

While other mechanisms like iron deficiency, B12/folate deficiency, and bone marrow fibrosis due to hyperparathyroidism may also contribute to anemia in CKD patients, EPO deficiency is considered a standard feature that occurs in patients with chronic kidney disease and can be effectively treated with exogenous EPO administration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aplastic anemia: Aplastic anemia is due to bone marrow failure with decreased production of all cell lines. EPO would not be effective as the problem is in the bone marrow's ability to respond to growth factors, not EPO deficiency.

 

Option B. Myelofibrosis: Myelofibrosis involves bone marrow fibrosis and extramedullary hematopoiesis. The anemia is due to marrow replacement and dysfunction, not EPO deficiency, so EPO therapy is not effective.

 

Option C. Nutritional anemia: Nutritional anemias (iron, B12, folate deficiency) require replacement of the specific deficient nutrient, not EPO therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythropoietin (EPO) is effective in treating anemia due to chronic kidney disease because EPO deficiency is a key pathophysiological mechanism in renal failure-associated anemia.

choices.text: An HLA identical matched unrelated donor who is blood type O-
His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia with a blood type O negative blood group presents to the transplant clinic to discuss proceeding with an allogeneic stem cell transplant. Which of the following would be an optimal donor? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+

 

  1. Due to the decreased risk of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) with related transplants, related donor transplants are still favored over unrelated donor transplants.
  2. Rh incompatibility has no impact on the success of transplants (Rh antigen is only found on the surface of RBCs, not on the parenchymal cells of the graft).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Syngeneic transplantation (donation from identical twins) has been shown to increase the risk of relapse in cases of hematologic malignancies and is therefore not a source of donor that is advised.

 

Option B: Umbilical cord transplant is not usually recommended.

 

Option C: While ABO compatibility is vital when selecting a donor, this is merely a slight ABO discrepancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with acute myeloid leukemia, the optimal donor choice would generally be an HLA identical sibling, despite any ABO blood type differences, due to the lower risk of complications and better overall survival outcomes. Blood type discrepancies, especially in Rh factor, are manageable in the context of stem cell transplants.

 

Reference - Harrison/Transplant/Chap 104

questions.text: A patient was treated for peptic ulcer with an H. pylori regimen. Which of the following is used to assess the success of treatment? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Urea breath test

 

The urea breath test is the preferred non-invasive method to assess the success of H. pylori eradication therapy. It works by detecting the presence of urease, an enzyme produced by H. pylori. During the test, the patient ingests a urea solution labeled with a carbon isotope. If H. pylori is present, the urease enzyme breaks down the urea, releasing labeled carbon dioxide, which is then measured in the patient's breath. This test is highly accurate, non-invasive, and convenient for follow-up, making it the best choice for confirming the eradication of H. pylori after treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoscopy: While endoscopy with a biopsy for a rapid urease test can be used to detect H. pylori, it is invasive and not ideal for follow-up assessments when less invasive options are available.

 

Option B. IgG antibody study: This test detects antibodies against H. pylori but is not useful for follow-up after treatment. Antibody levels can remain elevated for a long time even after the infection has been eradicated, leading to false-positive results.

 

Option D. Urease test of biopsy: This method, similar to endoscopy, involves an invasive procedure to obtain a gastric tissue sample for a rapid urease test. Although accurate, it is not preferred for follow-up due to its invasiveness compared to non-invasive options like the urea breath test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The urea breath test is the preferred non-invasive method for assessing the success of H. pylori eradication therapy due to its accuracy and convenience.

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

questions.text: A male patient presents with sensory loss and weakness of limbs for 3 months. He also has angular stomatitis. On examination, there is loss of proprioception, vibration sensations, UMN type of lower limb weakness, and absent ankle reflex. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

 

The patient presents with sensory loss, limb weakness, and specific neurological findings that are indicative of subacute combined degeneration of the cord due to vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Key Findings:

 

  1. Sensory Loss and Weakness of Limbs: This suggests a neurological disorder affecting the peripheral and central nervous systems.
  2. Angular Stomatitis: This is often associated with vitamin deficiencies, particularly vitamin B12.
  3. Loss of Proprioception and Vibration Sensation: This is characteristic of posterior column involvement, which is seen in subacute combined degeneration.
  4. UMN Type of Lower Limb Weakness: Upper motor neuron signs (UMN) such as spasticity and exaggerated reflexes, except for the absent ankle reflex, are indicative of corticospinal tract involvement.
  5. Absent Ankle Reflex: This, along with UMN signs, is a classic feature of subacute combined degeneration of the cord.

 

Subacute Combined Degeneration of the Cord: This condition is due to vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to demyelination of the posterior columns and corticospinal tracts. This results in a combination of sensory ataxia, spasticity, and other upper motor neuron signs, except for the absent ankle reflex which indicates peripheral neuropathy.

 

Additional Findings:

 

  • Angular Stomatitis: Points towards a vitamin deficiency.
  • Babinski Positivity with Absent Ankle Jerk: This combination is specifically associated with subacute combined degeneration of the cord due to B12 deficiency. Other conditions like cauda equina syndrome or Friedreich ataxia could present similarly, but the presence of angular stomatitis and the described neurological findings strongly support subacute combined degeneration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extradural Cord Compression: This would typically present with radicular pain and possibly more pronounced lower motor neuron signs below the level of compression, not the UMN signs described here.

 

Option B. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS): ALS involves both UMN and LMN signs but does not typically present with sensory loss or specific vitamin deficiency signs like angular stomatitis.

 

Option C. Multiple Sclerosis (MS): MS can present with varied neurological signs, but it does not typically present with angular stomatitis or the classic combination of absent ankle reflex with UMN signs seen in subacute combined degeneration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subacute combined degeneration of the cord due to vitamin B12 deficiency presents with sensory loss, UMN signs in the lower limbs, and absent ankle reflex, along with other signs of vitamin deficiency like angular stomatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is NOT associated with granulomatous pathology? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Polyarteritis nodosa (classic PAN)

 

Explanation:

 

Polyarteritis nodosa is characterized by a necrotizing inflammation of small and medium-sized muscular arteries, but it does not typically demonstrate granulomatous features. PAN is a panarteritis that involves neutrophil infiltration of all layers of the vessel wall with fibrinoid necrosis, leading to compromise of the vascular lumen, thrombosis, and tissue infarction. However, granuloma formation - a hallmark of many other vasculitides - is notably absent in classic PAN.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's):  it is characterized by necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis involving small arteries and veins. The histopathologic hallmarks include granuloma formation that may be intravascular or extravascular, which is crucial to its diagnosis.

 

Option B. Arteritis of Takayasu:  it demonstrates granulomatous inflammation of the vessel wall. The pathological features include granulomatous panarteritis with inflammatory mononuclear cell infiltrates and occasional giant cells.

 

Option D. Arteritis of the giant cell type:  it is defined by granulomatous vasculitis with giant cell formation. This is a panarteritis with inflammatory mononuclear cell infiltrates within the vessel wall and frequent giant cell formation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Classic polyarteritis nodosa is a necrotizing, non-granulomatous vasculitis of medium-sized arteries, distinguishing it from other major vasculitides like GPA, Takayasu arteritis, and Giant Cell Arteritis, which all demonstrate granulomatous inflammation.

questions.text: 60-year-old obese lady underwent cholecystectomy. After 3 days she develops respiratory distress. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pulmonary embolism

 

Explanation

 

The patient, an obese post-operative case following cholecystectomy, presents with respiratory distress three days after surgery. This is highly suggestive of a pulmonary embolism, particularly in the context of immobilization and the hypercoagulable state following surgery. Pulmonary embolism is a common and serious complication of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can occur due to immobilization and endothelial injury during surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Air embolism: This is less likely in this scenario as it typically occurs immediately during or after surgical procedures involving vascular access.

 

Option C. Atelectasis: While atelectasis can cause respiratory distress post-operatively, it typically does not cause sudden severe symptoms three days post-op.

 

Option D. Myocardial Infarction: Although possible, the context of recent surgery and immobilization makes pulmonary embolism a more likely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In post-operative patients, particularly those who are obese and immobilized, the development of sudden respiratory distress should raise suspicion for pulmonary embolism due to the increased risk of deep vein thrombosis and subsequent embolization. Prompt diagnosis and management are crucial.

 

Note - The rule of threes (in Immobilization) whenever the patient is immobilized for more than 72 hours/ >3 days in the last 3 months that is called significant immobilization and that increases the risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with weight gain, proximal muscle weakness, purple striae, and easy bruising. What is the likely underlying condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypercortisolism

 

Hypercortisolism, also known as Cushing's syndrome, is characterized by an excess of cortisol in the body. The clinical features of Cushing's syndrome include weight gain, particularly in the face, neck, and trunk, proximal muscle weakness, purple striae (stretch marks), and easy bruising. These symptoms are a result of the catabolic effects of cortisol on various tissues.

 

  • Weight Gain: Cortisol promotes the deposition of fat in specific areas, leading to central obesity.
  • Proximal Muscle Weakness: Cortisol has catabolic effects on muscle tissue, leading to muscle wasting and weakness, particularly in the proximal muscles.
  • Purple Striae: Cortisol weakens the skin by breaking down collagen, leading to the formation of purple striae.
  • Easy Bruising: Cortisol reduces the ability of blood vessels to repair themselves, causing increased bruising.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperthyroidism: This condition involves an excess of thyroid hormones, leading to symptoms such as weight loss, increased appetite, heat intolerance, and hyperactivity. It does not typically cause the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option C. Hyperparathyroidism: This condition involves an excess of parathyroid hormone, leading to hypercalcemia, bone pain, kidney stones, and abdominal pain. It does not cause the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option D. Hyperaldosteronism: This condition involves an excess of aldosterone, leading to hypertension and hypokalemia. It does not cause the symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cushing's syndrome, or hypercortisolism, is characterized by weight gain, proximal muscle weakness, purple striae, and easy bruising due to the catabolic effects of excess cortisol.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old female patient presents with a 3-day history of fever, headache, ataxia, nausea, and vomiting. On examination neck rigidity is present and there is hip and knee flexion on passive flexion of the neck. A lumbar puncture was done and CSF findings are as shown below. (FMGE JUNE 2022)

 

Opening pressure – Increased,

 

Colour- Cloudy white,

 

WBCs – 7000 PMNs predominant,

 

Glucose 15 mg/dL,

 

CSF/serum glucose ratio - 0.2,

 

Protein 70 mg/dL.

 

What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacterial meningitis

 

The presence of high opening pressure, cloudy CSF, high WBC count (predominantly neutrophils), low glucose, and elevated protein is indicative of bacterial meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tubercular meningitis: Typically shows lymphocytic predominance.

 

Option C. Viral meningitis: Shows lymphocytic predominance and normal glucose.

 

Option D. Fungal meningitis: Shows lymphocytic predominance and can have a varied glucose level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacterial meningitis is characterized by high neutrophil count, low glucose, and elevated protein in CSF.

choices.text: Supranuclear facial palsy on the left side
Infranuclear facial palsy on the right side
Supranuclear facial palsy on the right side
Infranuclear facial palsy on the left side

questions.text: A young man presents with drooping of the corner of his mouth and weakness in the lower half of the right side of his face. He can raise his eyebrows and close his eyes on both sides. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supranuclear facial palsy on the left side

 

Explanation:

 

This is a case of supranuclear (upper motor neuron) facial palsy affecting the right side of the face, which means the lesion is on the left side of the brain due to crossed innervation.

 

Key features supporting this diagnosis:

 

  • Only the lower half of the face is affected (sparing of the upper face)
  • Ability to raise eyebrows and close eyes bilaterally (preserved upper facial function)
  • Right-sided facial weakness indicates a left-sided lesion

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infranuclear facial palsy on the right side: Incorrect

 

  • Lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions affect the entire half of the face
  • Patients cannot raise their eyebrows or close their eyes on the affected side

 

Option C. Supranuclear facial palsy on the right side: Incorrect

 

  • Would cause left-sided lower facial weakness, not right-sided

 

Option D. Infranuclear facial palsy on the left side: Incorrect

 

  • Would cause left-sided full facial weakness

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supranuclear (UMN) facial palsy affects the lower face on the opposite side of the lesion, while LMN facial palsy affects the entire ipsilateral face.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in the ECG shown below?(INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mobitz type 2 block


The ECG shows bradycardia with regular, constant PR intervals in the conducted beats and intermittently dropped QRS complexes, which are indicative of Mobitz type 2 block. This type of atrioventricular block is characterized by:

 

  • Constant PR interval in the conducted beats
  • Intermittent non-conducted P waves (dropped QRS complexes)

 

This distinguishes Mobitz type 2 block from other types of heart block:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First degree heart block: Characterized by a prolonged PR interval (>200 ms) but all P waves are followed by QRS complexes. This is not observed in the given ECG.

 

Option B. Third degree heart block: Complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes, with no relationship between them. The given ECG does not show this pattern.

 

Option C. Wenckebach heart block (Mobitz type 1): Progressive prolongation of the PR interval until a QRS complex is dropped. The given ECG shows constant PR intervals, not progressively increasing.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Mobitz type 2 block is identified by a constant PR interval with intermittently non-conducted P waves. Recognizing this pattern is crucial for appropriate management, as Mobitz type 2 can progress to complete heart block and often requires a pacemaker.

choices.text: Rewarming is the treatment of choice

questions.text: A soldier operating in Siachen Glacier presents with numbness of his legs. Incorrect regarding the image given: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Analgesics are contraindicated

 

The patient described is likely suffering from frostbite, given the environmental conditions and symptoms of numbness and the visual sign of erythema on the toes. Frostbite occurs when skin and other tissues freeze due to exposure to extremely cold temperatures. The treatment and management of frostbite are critical to prevent long-term damage.

 

Analgesics are contraindicated: This is incorrect. Analgesics, especially opiate analgesics, are crucial during the rewarming process because it is extremely painful. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) should be avoided due to their potential to cause further vasoconstriction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rewarming is the treatment of choice: This is correct. The first line of treatment for frostbite is rapid rewarming in a water bath at 37-39Â°C (98.6-102.2Â°F). This helps to restore blood flow and minimize tissue damage.

 

Option C. Thrombolytics can be used: This is correct. In cases where frostbite is severe and the patient presents within 24 hours, thrombolytic therapy may be considered to restore blood flow and prevent tissue death. MR angiography can help assess the need for thrombolytics.

 

Option D. Amputation in severe cases: This is correct. In severe frostbite cases, where there is significant tissue necrosis, amputation may be necessary. This is typically decided based on a bone scan if the patient presents more than 24 hours after the injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For frostbite treatment, rewarming is essential, analgesics are indicated due to the pain associated with rewarming, thrombolytics can be used within 24 hours of injury, and amputation may be necessary in severe cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Pneumothorax? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased Chest Expansion.

 

Explanation:

 

In pneumothorax, air accumulates in the pleural space, causing the lung to collapse away from the chest wall. This leads to decreased chest expansion on the affected side. The physical examination findings in pneumothorax typically include an enlarged hemithorax with no breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion, and potentially a mediastinal shift to the contralateral side in tension pneumothorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased Breath Sounds: pneumothorax causes diminished or absent breath sounds on the affected side due to air in the pleural space separating the lung from the chest wall, preventing normal sound transmission.

 

Option C. Increased Vocal Resonance: pneumothorax actually decreases vocal resonance. The presence of air in the pleural space impedes sound transmission, resulting in decreased, not increased, vocal resonance.

 

Option D. Dull percussion note: pneumothorax produces a hyperresonant percussion note due to the presence of air in the pleural space. A dull percussion note would suggest fluid (as in pleural effusion) or consolidation (as in pneumonia).

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pneumothorax presents with classic physical findings of decreased chest expansion, absent breath sounds, and hyperresonant percussion on the affected side - the opposite of findings seen with pleural fluid or consolidation.

questions.text: A patient presented with sinusitis, ulcerative lesions on the nasopharynx, nodular lesions with cavitations of the lung, and renal failure. Which of the following is the most useful investigation in this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Test for ANCA


The clinical presentation of ENT involvement, lung nodules with cavitations, and renal failure suggests granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). The ANCA (anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies) test is a useful diagnostic tool for GPA.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Biopsy to show granulomas is useful but more invasive.

 

Option C. AFB staining of sputum is for TB, not GPA.

 

Option D. BAL (bronchoalveolar lavage):  is not specific for diagnosing GPA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected GPA, the ANCA test is the most useful initial investigation.

questions.text: A patient comes to the ER with a headache, describing it as the worst headache of his life. Initial NCCT shows SAH. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CT Angiography

 

Explanation:

 

The description of the "worst headache of his life" is highly suggestive of a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). When an initial non-contrast CT (NCCT) confirms SAH, the next step is to identify the source of bleeding, which is most commonly an aneurysm.

 

CT Angiography is the preferred next step to localize the aneurysm and plan further management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lumbar puncture: Indicated if the initial CT scan is negative and there is still suspicion of SAH, to check for xanthochromia.

 

Option C. MRI brain: Not the initial choice for acute SAH diagnosis or aneurysm localization.

 

Option D. V-P shunt: Used for hydrocephalus management, not for immediate SAH diagnosis and management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with confirmed subarachnoid hemorrhage on CT, the next step is CT Angiography to identify and localize the source of bleeding.

choices.text: Not associated with rise in Creatinine

questions.text: Acute graft rejection in a kidney transplant patient is indicated by: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Any rise in creatinine

 

In modern transplant medicine, acute graft rejection often presents subtly due to powerful immunosuppression regimens. The most common presentation of acute rejection in current clinical practice is an asymptomatic rise in serum creatinine. According to the definition, there should be at least a 25% increase in serum creatinine to diagnose acute rejection. However, in cases where antibody-mediated rejection (ABMR) is suspected, any rise in serum creatinine can lead to a diagnosis or at least a suspicion of acute rejection.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Creatinine raised by 5%: Incorrect because acute rejection is characterized by a rise in creatinine levels. Normal creatinine would not indicate rejection.

 

Option C. Creatinine raised by 10%: While this would also indicate rejection, the question asks for the earliest indicator, and any rise in creatinine (including 5%) should raise suspicion.

 

Option D. Not associated with rise in Creatinine: Incorrect because there is a clear association between creatinine rises and acute rejection. This is one of the most reliable indicators of rejection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute graft rejection in kidney transplant patients typically presents with asymptomatic elevation in serum creatinine. Traditional symptoms like fever and graft tenderness are less common due to current immunosuppression protocols. Any rise in creatinine should prompt consideration of acute rejection.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with AIDS presented with fever and productive cough. On auscultation, bronchial breath sounds and crepitations were heard in the right infra-scapular region. Chest X-ray showed right lower lobe consolidation. The CD4 count was 55 cells/mm3. What is the most common causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Streptococcus pneumoniae

 

In patients with AIDS, regardless of their CD4 count, the most common cause of bacterial pneumonia is Streptococcus pneumoniae. This organism is a leading cause of community-acquired pneumonia in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised patients.

 

The clinical presentation of fever, productive cough, bronchial breath sounds, and right lower lobe consolidation on chest X-ray is consistent with bacterial pneumonia. While Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly known as Pneumocystis carinii) is a common cause of pneumonia in AIDS patients with low CD4 counts, it typically presents with bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray and less commonly with lobar consolidation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumocystis jirovecii: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP) is common in AIDS patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/mm³. It usually presents with diffuse bilateral infiltrates rather than lobar consolidation.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus can cause pneumonia, especially post-viral or in hospital-acquired cases, but it is not the most common cause of pneumonia in AIDS patients. It can also present with abscess formation and necrotizing pneumonia, which were not described here.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma: Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of atypical pneumonia, especially in younger patients, but it is less likely in this immunocompromised patient with typical lobar consolidation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with AIDS, Streptococcus pneumoniae remains the most common cause of bacterial pneumonia, regardless of the CD4 count. This should be a primary consideration when evaluating pneumonia in this population.

questions.text: A person with dyspnea has slight limitation in physical activity and doing ordinary activity causes symptoms but he is asymptomatic at rest. Which class of New York Heart Association (NYHA) does he belong to? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Class II

 

NYHA Class II heart failure is characterized by slight limitation of physical activity. The patient is comfortable at rest, but ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitation, dyspnea, or angina. The key detail here is that ordinary activities cause symptoms, fitting the description of Class II.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Class I: Patients have no limitation of physical activity; ordinary physical activity does not cause symptoms.

 

Option C. Class III: Patients have marked limitation of physical activity; less than ordinary activity causes symptoms, but they are comfortable at rest.

 

Option D. Class IV: Patients have symptoms even at rest and are unable to carry out any physical activity without discomfort.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NYHA class âmost powerful prognostic marker of HF.

 

  • Class 1 - asymptomatic with ordinary activities
  • Class 2 - symptomatic with ordinary activities, not at rest
  • Class 3 - symptomatic with < ordinary activity
  • Class 4 - symptomatic at rest

questions.text: Which among the following indicates severe COVID-19 ? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) SpO2 < 85% on room air


Severe COVID-19 is characterized by a significant drop in oxygen saturation. An SpO2 of less than 85% on room air indicates severe hypoxemia.

 

Any SpO2 of less than 90% indicate severe COVID and 90-93% indicates moderate COVID

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. RR >24/min: Indicates moderate, not severe, COVID-19. RR>30/min indicate severe COVID
 

Option B. MAP 70 mmHg: Does not specifically indicate severe COVID-19. Hemodynamic instability i.e. MAP <65 OR 65 or above with vasopressors indicates severe COVID. 
 

Option C. Lung infiltrates >42% on CT: Not a specific criterion for COVID-19 severity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe COVID-19 is indicated by an SpO2 of less than 85% on room air.

questions.text: A patient with a history of TB presents with hemoptysis. X-ray is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspergilloma

 

The patient has a history of tuberculosis and now presents with hemoptysis. The chest X-ray shows a cavity with a mass inside it, which is suggestive of an aspergilloma, also known as a fungal ball.

 

Aspergilloma typically forms in pre-existing lung cavities caused by conditions such as tuberculosis. The fungal ball is composed of Aspergillus organisms and debris, and it often presents as a crescent-shaped shadow known as Monod's sign, although this may not always be clearly visible.

 

Most patients with aspergilloma are asymptomatic, but when symptoms do occur, hemoptysis is the most common presenting symptom, ranging from mild to life-threatening.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchogenic cancer: While bronchogenic cancer, particularly squamous cell carcinoma, can present with cavitating lesions, it is less likely in this case given the patient's history of TB and the appearance of the cavity with a mass, which is more typical of aspergilloma.

 

Option C. Lung abscess: Lung abscesses also present as cavitating lesions, but they typically show air-fluid levels on imaging, which are not evident in this X-ray.

 

Option D. Bronchogenic cyst: Bronchogenic cysts have a completely different radiographic appearance and clinical presentation. They are typically congenital and do not present as cavitating lesions with a mass inside them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspergilloma is a fungal infection that commonly occurs in pre-existing lung cavities from conditions such as tuberculosis. It presents as a cavity with a fungal ball inside and can cause hemoptysis, which may be severe.

questions.text: Which drug is used for mass chemoprophylaxis for meningococcal meningitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ciprofloxacin

 

Ciprofloxacin is commonly used for mass chemoprophylaxis in cases of meningococcal meningitis, particularly among close contacts of an infected individual. It is effective in preventing the spread of Neisseria meningitidis, the bacterium responsible for meningococcal disease. Ciprofloxacin is preferred due to its broad-spectrum activity, ease of administration as a single-dose regimen, and good penetration into the cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chloramphenicol: While used for treatment of meningococcal meningitis, it is not used for chemoprophylaxis.

 

Option C. Tetracycline: Not used in the prophylaxis or treatment of meningococcal meningitis.

 

Option D. Penicillin: Although used for treatment, penicillin is not typically used for prophylaxis against meningococcal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciprofloxacin, Rifampicin, Ceftriaxone is indicated in the chemoprophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis for close contacts to prevent secondary cases.

 

Ceftriaxone is preferred in children < 18 years and pregnancy.

questions.text: Which type of aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fluent aphasia

 

The posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus is where Wernicke's area is located, which is crucial for language comprehension. Lesions in this area lead to Wernicke's aphasia, which is a type of fluent aphasia. Patients with this type of aphasia exhibit fluent but often meaningless speech and have significant difficulties in understanding spoken language. Their speech is typically characterized by normal flow and articulation but includes nonsensical phrases and incorrect word substitutions (neologisms).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-fluent aphasia: This type of aphasia, typically associated with damage to Brocaâs area in the frontal lobe, results in slow, labored speech and struggle in forming words, though comprehension often remains intact.

 

Option C. Anomic aphasia: In anomic aphasia, the person can speak fluently and understand speech but has difficulty naming objects and words, typically not linked to damage in the superior temporal gyrus.

 

Option D. Conduction aphasia: This arises from damage to the arcuate fasciculus, the brain structure that connects Wernicke's area to Brocaâs area. It is characterized by fluent speech with frequent errors, good comprehension, but poor repetition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Regions anterior to the central sulcus are motor areas and posterior are sensory areas. Hence temporal gyrus involvement causes a fluent aphasia.

 

 

Reference - KV Krishna Das textbook of Medicine 5th edition
